production ready well surely

you know bug free or perfect
and that is not at all what we're

so for us what production ready really
means is that what you're building is

means that when you build something you
put it out there you know whether it's
working how it's working and if it's not
working you get alerted to it and you

but is actually something that is heard
and people know how to go and deal with

togetherness so togetherness you know in

and togetherness actually extends past

it can be dangerous if pragmatism gets

one of the things you mentioned when we

people who will be able to

when it started of course you know it

as if they're a fresh graduate out of

and then at the end of it it's sort of a

is
empathy and compassion and understanding

what small businesses are going through
maybe it's easier to teach people how to

what it does is creates this really

which feels like a really really solid
number another thing we have focused on
aside from that is focusing on what we

early in career midway experienced in

career
we want that to sort of look like a bell
curve and when you think about it you

where they're advanced in their career
and a hugely grossly over-generalized

the advanced folks are doing and these
super advanced folks are teaching now
all three cohorts should be doing all
three of those things all the time right
everyone is always teaching and learning

very carefully look at the size of the

org because it should look like that

we've got a little bit more on the

two then we will not hire so much in the

how are you tackling diversity
yeah so we are tackling diversity by
again being super intentional and i
think a mistake that leaders make when
they're talking about diversity is
saying you know i want to hire a certain
number of people from diverse
backgrounds i understand the approach
there and the the intent there but what
we have discovered is it's better to
have a secondary goal on certain numbers
and the primary goal being i want to
create an environment where people from
diverse backgrounds can be super
successful right and then if you think
about that then the numbers end up
coming right or it's possible that the
numbers can come because if you just
focus on i want to hire 50 from certain
diverse backgrounds you may hire them
and then they can't be successful so
they're going to just leave on the back
end right and retention and success
really is the key and really is the goal
if you really want to have a diverse
environment well retaining them and
making an environment where they can do
the best work of their careers is the
real goal it's not just having some sort
of number on my hiring head count or
numbers that i can go out and show it's
about being able to show that those
folks are able to be successful and that
you're intentional around all of that so
we do have those numbers where we're
looking at what pipelines look like and
all of that and we're focused on all

org i think people also make a mistake
of like let's bring in entry level folks
to fix diversity problems and no it
needs to be all across the board and we
need to make sure that we're hearing
from those folks about how they're
successful the other thing that we have

and what we do with that group is we're
super intentional about the diversity of
that group and then engineering
leadership decisions are run through
that group as an advisory board and we

whether those future decisions that

what advice for people who want to

what's been super successful is asking
myself how can i be helpful right so
when i came into this company i took it
as an opportunity to say what's my brand
been in my career what do i want my
brand to be going forward and i know
like thinking about yourself as a brand
is kind of icky but i thought about that
and i said you know some past career i
was the grumpy engineer the grumpy
engineer who didn't really listen a lot
i had a phenomenal manager teach me the

into this role i said well i want to be
known as the helpful engineer and the
helpful leader and so when i came in i
really took the time to tour every

were our finance department had the
biggest needs at the time so i did a lot

having that humble moment where you hire
the engineers that are just way better
than you so within the first year i was
here hired a couple of engineers and
just realized if i can figure out how to

them it's going to be way better for the

way way better at this than i am and so
maybe i'll try to learn how to do the

that in hindsight got me to the position

ask stakeholders those questions what do

that's really helped me along the way

one of the phrases you used when we were

there's a saying somewhere it may have

really cool quote and so as i think

some amount of time it'll feel magical
right like today our cell phones are not
indistinguishable from magic but if you

extrapolate that as i say the best
products that we build have a short
distance to magic right the amount of
time you have to go back for someone to
go whoa that's magical
really is sort of a litmus for how great
the piece of technology is and the thing
that i think is really empowering and
sort of great for folks to think about
there is it doesn't actually have to be
super complex and amazing technology
right like an example is google
translate you know if you bring up
translate on your phone and you hold it
up to something and it translates the
image in real time it's just like
unbelievably magical i think most
engineers look at that and go that's a
pretty high bar eric like making
something that's as magical as holding
my phone up that translates it is a
pretty high bar but i think we have to
remember that there's also magic in the
way a piece of software can just make

you're struggling with a certain task
and just says hey i see you're

just throws up an empathetic emoji at a

when customers hit the send button you

with his fingers sweating bouncing up

like are you sure and just that little
image
showing people that we understand the
sweaty moment of pressing send to
thousands hundreds of thousands maybe

down the road one of my other super

as a clock and he was like well they're

actually be the time the campaign is

think he was able to get it done in a
